subject.display: 56-year-old male gardener with type 2 diabetes mellitus and central diabetes insipidus

encounter.display: Inpatient admission for evaluation of persistent polyuria and polydipsia

text.div: The patient is a 56-year-old male gardener who presents with a two-month history of profound thirst and excessive urination, describing it as "an unstoppable need to drink cold water all day and night, like my body is on fire from the inside." This relentless polydipsia has driven him to consume over 8 liters of refrigerated water daily—equivalent to about 10 bottles of 750 ml capacity—while experiencing frequent polyuria that disrupts his sleep and daily work routine, leading to nocturia that wakes him multiple times nightly.

Building on his chief complaint, the patient, a 56-year-old male gardener, first noticed the insidious onset of excessive thirst and urination approximately two months prior to admission. Initially, he visited a local clinic where he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) based on a fasting blood sugar of 150 mg/dL. He was started on an oral hypoglycemic agent, which improved his hyperglycemia, yet his symptoms persisted unabated. Despite glycemic control, he continued to drink more than 8 liters of cold water daily and pass large volumes of urine frequently, often exceeding 10 liters per day as later quantified. This polyuria and polydipsia significantly impacted his quality of life, causing sleep fragmentation from nocturia—waking him 4-5 times per night—and fatigue during his physically demanding outdoor work as a gardener, where access to water and restrooms became constant challenges, increasing risks of mild dehydration in hot conditions. He denied any precipitating events such as head trauma, and reported no associated symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or neurologic deficits. His weight had decreased from 71 kg to 68 kg over this period, reflecting mild chronic volume depletion from unchecked fluid losses, though he remained resilient in maintaining his livelihood without seeking earlier specialist care. Prior to this, his health was unremarkable, with no family history of similar endocrine disorders.

Transitioning to his background, the patient is a 56-year-old male with no significant past medical history prior to the onset of his current symptoms. He reports a lifetime of robust health, with no chronic medical conditions, prior hospitalizations, or surgical interventions. He has never been diagnosed with hypertension, cardiovascular disease, or other endocrine issues, and denies any history of mental health disorders, substance use, or allergies. As a lifelong gardener working outdoors, he maintains an active lifestyle, which likely contributed to his resilience despite the emerging symptoms, though he notes that the recent polyuria has heightened his risk of dehydration during hot weather exposure. His immunizations are up to date, and he takes no regular medications other than the recently initiated oral hypoglycemic for DM.

Upon admission, the patient is a 56-year-old male who appears well-nourished and in no acute distress, though subtle signs of chronic volume depletion are evident, consistent with his reported history of massive fluid turnover. He measures 176 cm in height and weighs 68 kg, with a body mass index of approximately 22 kg/m². Vital signs include blood pressure of 132/70 mmHg, pulse rate of 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and temperature of 36.8°C. His skin shows mild dryness and tenting, suggestive of ongoing insensible losses, but no edema, jaundice, or pallor. Head, eyes, ears, nose, and throat examination is unremarkable, with moist oral mucosa despite his thirst complaints. The neck is supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals regular heart sounds and clear lung fields, with no murmurs or wheezes. Abdominal exam is soft and nontender, without organomegaly. Neurologic evaluation is intact, with no focal deficits, tremors, or altered mental status. Extremities show no clubbing or cyanosis, and his overall demeanor reflects the endurance of a manual laborer adapting to debilitating symptoms.

Laboratory and diagnostic findings upon admission revealed controlled hyperglycemia consistent with the patient's recent type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosis, yet incompatible with the severity of his polyuria and polydipsia, prompting further investigation into alternative causes of this polyuric state. Complete blood count showed white blood cell count of 9,700/mm³, hemoglobin of 13.4 g/dL, and platelets of 376 × 10³/mm³, all within normal limits. Serum electrolytes included sodium 140 mEq/L, potassium 3.8 mEq/L, blood urea nitrogen 12 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.0 mg/dL, with serum osmolality at 295 mOsm/kg water. Glycemic markers indicated HbA1c of 7.2% and postprandial glucose around 180 mg/dL, with fasting blood sugar of 140 mg/dL, confirming adequate initial DM control. Urine analysis demonstrated pH 6.0, specific gravity 1.006, negative albumin and glucose, with 0-4 WBC/HPF and 0-2 RBC/HPF, and notably low urine osmolality of 140 mOsm/kg water, suggesting impaired concentrating ability unrelated to osmotic diuresis. Twenty-four-hour fluid balance recorded 9 L oral intake and 11.7 L urine output. Hormone assays were unremarkable: ACTH 25.2 pg/mL (reference 6.0-76.0 pg/mL), prolactin 8 µg/L (0-15 µg/L), cortisol 9.8 µg/dL (5-25 µg/dL), hGH 2.26 ng/mL (0.5-17 ng/mL), TSH 0.99 µU/mL (0.5-4.7 µU/mL), and normal angiotensin-converting enzyme activity (<40 U/L). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the sella was normal, ruling out structural hypothalamic or pituitary pathology.

On hospital day 5, a water deprivation test (Miller-Moses protocol) was performed due to persistent symptoms despite glycemic stability. During the test, the patient lost 3 kg (4.4% body weight), with urine osmolality remaining hypotonic below 130 mOsm/kg and no increment in basal ADH (5.18 pg/mL) to post-dehydration levels (3.95 pg/mL) despite serum osmolality rising from 285-295 to 300 mOsm/kg. Administration of one puff (5 µg) desmopressin nasal spray resulted in urine osmolality increasing to 266 mOsm/kg (>100% from baseline 126 mOsm/kg) and urine output reducing from 200-410 mL/hr to 44-60 mL/hr, confirming antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency with preserved renal response.

This 56-year-old male gardener presents with a two-month history of severe polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia, initially attributed to osmotic diuresis from newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM), but ultimately confirmed as idiopathic central diabetes insipidus (CDI) through a meticulous diagnostic odyssey emphasizing the critical need to differentiate polyuric etiologies. The patient's resilience as an outdoor worker highlights his adaptive capacity, yet underscores risks such as mild dehydration and heat-related illness from unchecked fluid losses impacting sleep and productivity. Laboratory findings demonstrated controlled DM (HbA1c 7.2%) with low urine osmolality (140 mOsm/kg) and high output (11.7 L/day), incompatible with osmotic causes. The water deprivation test was pivotal, revealing absent ADH response to hyperosmolality but robust concentrating ability post-desmopressin (>100% urine osmolality rise), diagnostic of CDI. Normal MRI and hormone panel support an idiopathic etiology, with no evidence of systemic or infiltrative disease. Comorbid type 2 DM requires ongoing management, but does not contribute to the primary polyuria. Overall, this case illustrates the value of endocrinologic evaluation in unexplained polyuria, integrating lifestyle considerations for this active patient.

The patient will be initiated on desmopressin nasal spray (Minirin®) at 10 µg/day, administered as one puff (5 µg) every 12 hours, to address the confirmed central diabetes insipidus (CDI), with monitoring for response in urine output and thirst, targeting reduction to <3 L/day as achieved inpatient. For comorbid type 2 DM, continue metformin (Novamet GR® 500 mg twice daily) alongside American Diabetes Association-recommended diet, aiming for fasting blood sugar <115 mg/dL; post-discharge glycemic follow-up in 1-2 weeks. Multidisciplinary management includes endocrinology outpatient visit in 4 weeks for desmopressin titration and annual pituitary MRI surveillance, alongside primary care for holistic care addressing work-related dehydration risks—counseling on hydration strategies during gardening and sleep hygiene to mitigate nocturia impacts. Educate on hyponatremia avoidance with desmopressin, with fluid intake ad libitum but not exceeding thirst. Discharge on hospital day 9 with resolved intense symptoms, markedly reduced urine output to 2-3 L/day, and improved quality of life, including better sleep and work tolerance.

code.text: Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosis with fasting blood sugar 150 mg/dL

note.text: Diagnosed based on fasting blood sugar of 150 mg/dL
Daily fluid intake >8 liters, part of history
Daily urine output >10 liters with nocturia 4-5 times/night
Weight decreased from 71 kg to 68 kg over two months

resource.conclusion: MRI of sella: normal, no structural pathology

note.text: Rise from baseline 285-295 mOsm/kg during water deprivation test

code.text: Endocrinology outpatient visit for desmopressin titration and monitoring

coding.display: Magnetic resonance imaging of pituitary fossa (procedure)

code.text: Primary care follow-up for holistic care and dehydration risk management
